pullRequest.body:
* Make the namespace `asPowers` to simplify/shorten names when working primarily with the power algebra construction of the free product
    * Also adds related some convenience API to `rel'`
* Add simp shortcut attribute to `lift_comp_ι` and add simp shortcut lemma `lift_algebraMap`
* Replaces some `aesop` calls with `simp_rw` for performance

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [4ef59dd68f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15686/commits/4ef59dd68feb3d844fdca1bf63a0482741fd1ea2)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ PowerAlgebra.ofDirectSum_ι`
`+ PowerAlgebra.ι`
`+ asPowers`
`+ equiv_asPowers`
`+ identify_one`
`+ lift_algebraMap`
`+ lof_map_one`
`+ mul_injections`
`+ rel'_cases`
`+ rel'_id`
`+ rel'_prod`
`+ rel_prod`
`+ ι_apply`
`+ ι_equiv_ι`
`+ ι_equiv_ι'`
`- _root_.LinearAlgebra.FreeProduct_ofPowers`
`- equivPowerAlgebra`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Just looking at the module docstring of this file -- it claims that in the category of commutative $R$-algebras, the coproduct is just `PiTensorProduct`. I think PiTensorProduct is much too big to be the coproduct if the indexing set is infinite. For example I think a countably infinite PiTensorProduct of 1-dimensional vector spaces over the rationals or reals is uncountably infinite-dimensional, because e.g. 1 tensor 1 tensor 1 tensor ... and 2 tensor 2 tensor 2 tensor ... are linearly independent (one is "infinitely bigger than the other"). What do you think?

```suggestion
  /--`rel` relates the image of any `(1 : A i)` to `1`.-/
```

```suggestion
  /--`rel` relates the product of the images of two terms from the same `A i` to the image of their
```
What is the logic here? Do you want both `rel.id` and `rel_id`?

pullRequest.title: refactor (LinearAlgebra/FreeProduct): move PowerAlgebra construction to its own namespace, minor simp opts

source.title: feat(LinearAlgebra/FreeProduct): add induction principle, further simp opts for lift

nodes.body: Just looking at the module docstring of this file -- it claims that in the category of commutative $R$-algebras, the coproduct is just `PiTensorProduct`. I think PiTensorProduct is much too big to be the coproduct if the indexing set is infinite. For example I think a countably infinite PiTensorProduct of 1-dimensional vector spaces over the rationals or reals is uncountably infinite-dimensional, because e.g. 1 tensor 1 tensor 1 tensor ... and 2 tensor 2 tensor 2 tensor ... are linearly independent (one is "infinitely bigger than the other"). What do you think?
